parent - and the whole process of reproduction 
as it is manifested in Salpa A is one of gemmation 
<u>Salpa B is a bud of Salpa A <\u> -
Following the same course of investigation 
with regard to <s>Salpa<\s> the young Salpa A; (which it has
been seen is produced from Salpa B) - it is found,
that in Salpae B, which are either still adherent 
to the gemmiferous tube or just set free - there 
is no protuberance of the inner tunic into the 
respiratory cavity - but where this <s>[text?]<\s> afterwards 
<s>[text?]<\s> exists, a pedicle of greater or less length is attached 
and running backwards carries at its extremity an 
oval cellular mass (II fig 8) This hangs suspended 
by its pedicle in the cavity of the sinus, and is freely 
bathed by the blood - In one specimen the length 
of the pedicle was 1/250 of an inch - the long diameter 
of the oval body - about 1/600 of an inch.
In still younger forms of the Salpa B and indeed as soon as 
the separate organs are distinguishable:- the outer 
tunic bulges slightly in the middle line behind the outline of the 
posterior aperture and beneath the nucleus -; (II fig 1.2)
this protuberance is caused by the presence of a spherical 
body (9) about 1/1000 of an inch in diameter containg a 
clear vesicle 1/1700th of an inch in diameter - which again 
frequently contains a round opaque spot or nucleus, about 
1/8000th of an inch in diameter - the latter sometimes 
appeared as a thick walled vesicle - This is 
plainly an ovum - a narrow pedicle (9’) is attached 
to its upper extremity and runs upwards, curving 
slightly forwards, to the same point as in the 
preceding forms -
It would appear then that the Salpa B developes 
a high ovum, which is at first placed in the 
median line in the ventral sinus - that partly 
by the increase in size of the body <s>of the <\s> and partly
